title: Stage Manager iOS: The Intersection of Bugs Missing Features and Flawed Design
How do you get things done when working on something unfamiliar?
text:
Hi! Very often I seem to struggle to get anything done when I’m working on an unfamiliar subject, specially when I struggle with the documentation. This is not a rant about bad documentation, but an attempt to learn about some stories and strategies from people that can always seem to get things done even in a situation where the documentation isn’t for total beginners and they don’t also have the correct background.

A good example is Prometheus. I struggle with their documentation, but I feel I’m missing some background knowledge as well, but I don’t even know where to get it.

Another one is AWS. I’ve tried to use AWS ECS with an EC2 launcher but I failed to do it by myself. I later found a GitHub example, but I really don’t know what I’m doing.

How do you get your work done in these situations (let’s assume the final answer is not just a couple of Google searches away)? Do you just go down the rabbit whole of whatever seems to be the required background knowledge? Is it trial-an-error? If so, how do you it’s done right and you’re not overlooking anything major when you don’t understand all the variables involved in the problem?

I hope this question isn’t too vague and you’re able to understand the kind of advice I’m chasing.

Ask HN: Are seed oils truly bad for you?
text: Massive amounts of conflicting info on this. Seems to be a topic du jour in nutrition. I know smart people who have very different views on this. Some say it's borderline conspiracy nonsense pushed by uninformed guys like Joe Rogan, others say it's a legit health risk in line with well-known hazards of overly processed foods. What does HN think?

Ask HN: Job Advice – Startup or SME?
text:
Hello!

I've an excellent bsc in cs and now I applied for a fullstack position for both a startup and a medium sized enterprise. The startup deals with weather and offers the clients an API. The Tech stack is Python in the back end and React/Angular in the frontend. Language is english thus international. 3 days home office. The SME on the other hand has legacy code to deal with based on java and vaadin at one division or php and vue on the other. It's at minimum 1 day home office but I got told! that it could be 2 or 3 after three months in. The spoken language is local to the country thus not international and the company is well known. I've already met the people at the SME when I made a visit for a day. Both pay the same. Now I'm asking myself whether I should start at a well known company with legacy code and boring tech and less home office available but nice perks like food and atmosphere or should I work at interesting tech at the startup with vibey people and more home office available? What leads to a better career path and where could I potentially specialize further? I was told at the startup interview that I have to be prepared to do a lot of context switching. Also I got diagnosed with ADD and I'm a little bit socially anxious.

Thanks for reading all this. Sorry for my english.
